docs.snippet: EVERY time Adrian Smith opens his garage door in suburban Anderson Township outside of Cincinnati, a 20-year-old, pale blue Ford Galaxie convertible reawakens memories of his only National Basketball Association All-Star Game appearance. The car w...
docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY time Adrian Smith opens his garage door in suburban Anderson Township outside of Cincinnati, a 20-year-old, pale blue Ford Galaxie convertible reawakens memories of his only National Basketball Association All-Star Game appearance. The car was the prize for his selection as the most valuable player in the 1966 game. ''With the exception of a new set of tires, the car is exactly the way it was when I drove it away that afternoon,'' said Smith. ''It has been driven about 40,000 miles. I drive it about 10 or 15 miles a week to keep the motor in shape. When I do, people just stare.''

docs.snippet: FANTASIZE for a moment. You are an above-average guard in the National Basketball Association - about 6 feet 4 inches tall, with decent quickness and good defensive instincts. You are near midcourt, backpedaling as the opposition grabs a defensive...
docs.lead_paragraph: FANTASIZE for a moment. You are an above-average guard in the National Basketball Association - about 6 feet 4 inches tall, with decent quickness and good defensive instincts. You are near midcourt, backpedaling as the opposition grabs a defensive rebound and quickly gets the ball to its point guard, who ignites a fast break. Here's the catch: leading the fast break is the most commanding playmaker in the game, Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers. The first thing that strikes you is his size. He's 6-9, three inches taller than any other starting point guard in the league. Then you notice his eyes. They are sparkling, darting left and right, surveying the space between you and the basket. Streaking down the floor to Johnson's right is James Worthy, the graceful 6-9 forward who is a first-time all-star this season. Filling the left lane is Michael Cooper, perhaps the game's best reserve. So, what is Johnson thinking?

docs.snippet: In a race too close to call, Costa Rican presidential candidates face the voters Sunday after a yearlong campaign that has concentrated on the failing economy and bitter criticism of Nicaragua as a Marxist dictatorship.   The election comes at a t...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a race too close to call, Costa Rican presidential candidates face the voters Sunday after a yearlong campaign that has concentrated on the failing economy and bitter criticism of Nicaragua as a Marxist dictatorship. The election comes at a troubled time for Costa Rica, the only established democracy in Central America and by far the most affluent, least violent and best educated society in the region. A $4.5 billion foreign debt incurred from financing inefficient public agencies has crippled the economy and forced small currency devaluations every few months. In addition, each of the last three Governments has engaged in large-scale corruption, prompting growing public mistrust of state officials.

headline.main: COSTA RICANS VOTE TODAY IN A TIGHT PRESIDENTIAL RACE

byline.original: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: As January moview go in any year - and they go pretty far in all directions at once - it would be difficult to top Rene Feret's ''Mystery of Alexina'' for unexpected, completely unintentional comedy portrayed with such sobersided solemnity.   Base...
docs.lead_paragraph: As January moview go in any year - and they go pretty far in all directions at once - it would be difficult to top Rene Feret's ''Mystery of Alexina'' for unexpected, completely unintentional comedy portrayed with such sobersided solemnity. Based on the true story of Adelaide Herculine Barbin, who lived in rural France in the second half of the 19th century, the new French film explores the mystery of a young French schoolteacher who, at age 22, is suddenly revealed to be not a young woman but a young man. This rather amazing revelation occurs when the schoolteacher, called Alexina in the film, and her pretty, flirty fellow-teacher, Sara, have been wrestling girlishly atop a bed. Amid the tossing of petticoats, Alexina becomes carried away by strange longings for Sara and does something out of character, or, at least, out of the character that apparently she and everyone else in the film have assumed to be hers. The saucy Sara, far from being affronted, couldn't be more delighted. Her comment, which may well stand as the movie understatement of 1986: ''You're not like other girls!''

docs.snippet: Musicalette: noun, from the Italian, musicaletto, songs sung in a piazza, free and al fresco.   In modern show business parlance, an anthology of songs, and sometimes dances, masquerading as a musical. A musicalette is connected by music or lyrics...
docs.lead_paragraph: Musicalette: noun, from the Italian, musicaletto, songs sung in a piazza, free and al fresco. In modern show business parlance, an anthology of songs, and sometimes dances, masquerading as a musical. A musicalette is connected by music or lyrics of the same authorship or by thematic content. There is often an attempt to offer biographical and/or historical information in the guise of entertainment. See also musical revue, songbook, catalogue musical. No such definition appears in the dictionary, but perhaps it is time for the coinage and for reevaluation of what is often a self-defeating theatrical form. Most musicalettes fail, yet every year at least several new, or new-old, ones open. So far this season there have been three: ''Jerome Kern Goes to Hollywood,'' ''Uptown . . . It's Hot!'' and ''Jerry's Girls.'' One reason for the continuing interest on the part of producers is the common misconception that all one has to do is secure the rights to a musical body of work, or stake out a period in musical history. In fact, the musical revue is one of the most difficult shows to create.

headline.main: IT TAKES MORE THAN A FEW SONGS TO MAKE A MUSICAL

docs.snippet: More than 2,200 city police officers and Federal agents swept down on hundreds of illegal betting parlors across the city yesterday in a raid the police said was aimed at crippling an organized-crime syndicate run by Cubans.   The law-enforcement ...
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 2,200 city police officers and Federal agents swept down on hundreds of illegal betting parlors across the city yesterday in a raid the police said was aimed at crippling an organized-crime syndicate run by Cubans. The law-enforcement officers - the largest joint force ever assembled in the city, officials said - gathered before dawn to organize for the 11:30 A.M. raid. Working in six-man teams and backed up by city patrol cars, they struck at 470 places, in all boroughs except Staten Island. The police made only 11 arrests. But they said the purpose of the raid -code-named ''Operation Marlin'' -was to gather evidence that they hope will lead to the indictment of the leaders of the crime syndicate, which they said was known as ''the company.''

headline.main: 470 BETTING PLACES RAIDED IN MOVE AGAINST SYNDICATE

docs.snippet: Haunting Manhattan, often long after midnight, a small group of young men and women are creating everything from monsters to pop-music heros out of yards of celluloid and miles of imagination.   They are independent film makers, their number in Ne...
docs.lead_paragraph: Haunting Manhattan, often long after midnight, a small group of young men and women are creating everything from monsters to pop-music heros out of yards of celluloid and miles of imagination. They are independent film makers, their number in New York is second only to the number in Los Angeles, and they are not interested in working for Hollywood. They can often be found in the third row of any movie house, especially when the film has good special effects. And unwary audiences are usually watched as avidly as anything on the screen. At 3 A.M. not long ago, residents still awake in TriBeCa could spy a group of independent film makers shooting an actor as he ran naked through the streets. Another night, traffic was all but stopped when the same actor hung by a harness from a hotel sign three stories up.

headline.main: YOUNG FILM MAKERS: A LIFE OF NIGHT WORK

docs.snippet: Larry Adler, a master of the instrument that he chooses to call the mouth organ (others may say harmonica), is bringing three key figures in his long and celebrated career to perform with him tonight and tomorrow at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Str...
docs.lead_paragraph: Larry Adler, a master of the instrument that he chooses to call the mouth organ (others may say harmonica), is bringing three key figures in his long and celebrated career to perform with him tonight and tomorrow at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). One is the tap- dancer Paul Draper, with whom Mr. Adler toured with great success 40 years ago when he played and Mr. Draper danced to classical music, jazz and Broadway tunes. The partnership was broken up in 1948 when Mr. Adler was blacklisted for refusing to identify friends as Communists. This is their first formal appearance together since then. The second celebrated figure from Mr. Adler's past will be the pianist Ellis Larkins. When Mr. Adler agreed in 1963 to make his first appearance in the United States since his blacklisting, he did it on condition that Mr. Larkins be his pianist. Mr. Larkins has remained Mr. Adler's favorite accompanist and, after joining Mr. Adler this week, he will continue to play with him at the Ballroom until his engagement ends on March 1.
